section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Sections 6.1 and 6.2 of Applied Discrete Structures. Relations are propositions between two variables that are boolean - they are either true or false. You've used them many times in the past without necessarily calling them by that name. For example, less than is a relation on the integers. 3 \lt 6 is true, while 6 \lt 3 is false. If we imagine all pairs of integers, (a,b), that make a \lt b true, that set is identified as the relation less than.

statement.p:
Although any subset of a cartesian product of a set with itself can be a relation on that set, in the long run we are most concerned with a few important ones. Three examples of very important relations are
Less than or equal to,\leq, on the integers,
Set containment, \subseteq, on the power set of a set,
Logical implication, \Rightarrow, on any set of propositions.
Discuss any similarities you see between these three relations.\vspace{10pt}

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p: Consider the two relations on people: M, where aMb if a's mother is b; and S, where aSb if a and b are siblings. Describe, in words, the two relations MS and SM in simple English terms.
Let A = \{1,2,3,4,6,12\}. Draw a digraph for the relation divides on A.

Let S be the set of rooms on the floor of the building that includes your classroom. Draw a digraph of the relation c, where s_1 c s_2 if and only if s_1 is connected to s_2 with at least one doorway.

li.p: The divisors of 100 is the set of integers D_{100}=\{1,2,4,5,10,20,25,50,100\}. Draw a digraph of the relation divides on D_{100}, but do not draw in the self loops on each vertex even though we know they are present.

Define the relation \delta on the set G=\{0,1,2\}^2 by (j,k) \delta (s,t) \Leftrightarrow j\leq s\textrm{ and }k\leq t. For example, (2,1)\delta (2,2), but (2,1)\delta (1,2) is false. Draw a digraph of the relation \delta, but do not draw in the self loops on each vertex even though we know they are present.
Compare the two relations and their digraphs.

statement.p: Given s and t, relations on \mathbb{Z}, s = \{(1, n) : n \in \mathbb{Z}\} and t= \{(n, 1) : n \in \mathbb{Z}\}, what are st and ts? Hint: Even when a relation involves infinite sets, you can often get insights into them by drawing partial graphs.

Let A be the set of strings of 0's and 1's of length 2 or less. This includes the empty string, \lambda, which is the only string of length zero.
Define the relation of w on A by x w y if x has the same number of 1's as y. For example, 01 w 100, but 01 w 101 is false. Draw a digraph for this relation.
Do the same for the relation p defined by x p y if x is a prefix of y. For example, 10 p 101, but 01 p 101 is false.
Consider logical implication, \Rightarrow, on the set of propositions \{0,1,p,q,p\lor q, p\land q, p\land p \}. Draw a digraph of this relation.
